user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_session:
```c
static struct Session *
get_session (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct Session *ret;
  const char *cookie;

  cookie = MHD_lookup_connection_value (connection,
                                        MHD_COOKIE_KIND,
                                        COOKIE_NAME);
  if (cookie != NULL)
  {
    /* find existing session */
    ret = sessions;
    while (NULL != ret)
    {
      if (0 == strcmp (cookie, ret->sid))
        break;
      ret = ret->next;
    }
    if (NULL != ret)
    {
      ret->rc++;
      return ret;
    }
  }
  /* create fresh session */
  ret = calloc (1, sizeof (struct Session));
  if (NULL == ret)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "calloc error: %s\n", strerror (errno));
    return NULL;
  }
  /* not a super-secure way to generate a random session ID,
     but should do for a simple example... */
  snprintf (ret->sid,
            sizeof (ret->sid),
            "%X%X%X%X",
            (unsigned int) rand (),
            (unsigned int) rand (),
            (unsigned int) rand (),
            (unsigned int) rand ());
  ret->rc++;
  ret->start = time (NULL);
  ret->next = sessions;
  sessions = ret;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions were found in the provided code fragment. I checked for common explicit language extensions that compilers document as non-standard, including but not limited to:

- GNU/Clang extensions: no use of __attribute__, __extension__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), or label-as-values (&&label).
- Microsoft extensions: no __declspec, __inline (MS-specific), or other MSVC keywords.
- Nested functions or block-level function definitions (a GCC extension) are not present.
- Inline asm or asm() usage is not present.
- Use of compiler-specific pragmas or #pragma directives is not present in the fragment.
- No zero-length arrays or other non-standard array declarations are present in the shown code. (Note: the definition of struct Session is not provided; usage of sizeof(ret->sid) assumes sid is an array with a compile-time size. If sid were a flexible array member, that would be a separate concern, but nothing in this function itself uses language extensions.)

Other constructs in the function (calloc, snprintf, casts, pointer usage, standard library calls like time, rand, strerror, fprintf, strcmp, NULL checks) are standard C library or standard C language usage, not compiler-specific extensions. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 for language extensions.
